awd_titl_txt: Physics Frontier Center at the Joint Quantum Institute
awd_abstract_narration:
Physicists' understanding of quantum mechanical phenomena has surpassed the stage of simple observation and measurement. Advances in atomic, molecular, and optical physics (AMO) and condensed matter physics (CM) have enabled explorations into the control over quantum systems with a goal of achieving quantum engineering. Through this Physics Frontiers Centers award the Physics Frontiers Center at the Joint Quantum Institute (PFC@JQI) will build on research conducted during the previous award to study many-body physics by the controlling and monitoring of quantum complexity in a systematic way. This will be done by both the intricate building and examination of materials using a wide range of platforms spanning both AMO and CM.  The PFC@JQI will continue to reach out to underrepresented groups through programs such as the Summer Girls Program which is a two-week intensive, hands-on physics program for high school students. The Center will also participate in other outreach and education programs geared to a range of audiences from the general public to K-12 students to graduate education.

The PFC@JQI will investigate experimental and theoretical areas related to quantum many-body physics at the interface of AMO and CM. Research areas will include: studies of topological matter (where energy bands determine the nature and behavior of the matter) such as Majorana fermion physics and new platforms for programmable topological matter; the use of quantum optical systems to explore many-body physics through coupling between, or mediated by, photons in atomic or photonic media; and the study of nonequilibrium quantum dynamics of many-body interacting systems using atomic and condensed matter systems through a close collaboration of experimentalists and theorists.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Physics Frontier Center at the Joint Quantum Institute (PFC@JQI) studied quantum coherent phenomena, encompassing atomic, molecular, and optical (AMO), and condensed matter (CM) physics, with a particular emphasis on the overlapping concepts of AMO and CM systems and their relationship to Quantum Information Science (QIS). The frontiers ran the gamut of modern many-particle quantum mechanics including, but not limited to, quantum entanglement, quantum correlation, quantum information, quantum phase transitions, topological matter, non-Abelian statistics, and nonequilibrium quantum dynamics. The study required experiment, theory, and simulation, and merges activities of a major university and national laboratory in a seamless, synergistic manner. 

PFC@JQI performed high-risk/high-return research, with exciting and important experimental and theoretical activities in areas related to quantum many-body physics at the AMO/CM interface. 

An important result that the PFC@JQI has enabled among the students is a breaking down of intellectual barriers among the AMO, CM, and QIS. A witness to this was the seed funding program that enabled graduate students and postdoctoral associates to team up together to make interdisciplinary research proposals. This led to several new research directions that was later pursued at JQI and other institutes. 

We were committed to enhancing the educational environment of our larger community with activities ranging from K-12 through graduate education and outreach to the public, from local venues to the national and international stages.


 

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2022
Modified by: William D Phillips
